awd_titl_txt: RUI: Adding Spin to a Gravitational Wave Detector Simulator
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent detection of the tiny ripples in space and time known as gravitational waves has prompted astronomers to consider new ways to build more sensitive gravitational-wave detectors. This project will develop, test, and share a flexible computer app that simulates how future detectors might react to binary star systems, the most important source of gravitational waves. This model will explore how well different designs perform, and it will cross-check the detector models of other groups in this exciting new area of astronomical research. This project will give valuable research experience to college students at a crucial time in their education. It will also give high school, college, and graduate-level educators new teaching resources on gravitational-wave astronomy, detector physics, and the strange phenomenon of gravitomagnetism.

The dawning of gravitational wave astronomy and the prospect of new gravitational wave detectors have made determining how to best use such detectors a critical task for the gravity research community. This project supports completion of a computer application that models the gravitational waves generated by inspiraling binary star systems with spin, simulates their detection, and estimates the uncertainties that detector noise introduces into determinations of system characteristics. This work will involve (1) perfecting the addition of precessing stellar spin to the model, (2) thoroughly testing the model against simulations from various research groups, (3) using the tested model to generate results valuable to the field, and (4) creating a web portal granting  public access to the model software, documentation, and educational materials. This model is distinctive in providing a time-domain-based analysis that includes higher-order harmonics in the waveform as well as a natural way to perform controlled comparisons of different detector designs, and so will be a valuable and accessible tool for the research community to compare with other models and to use for further research. This project will also support research experiences for a number of undergraduates and delivers new online teaching resources for educators at a variety of levels for teaching students about related physics topics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Detection of gravitational waves has already deepened our understanding of the universe, and new detectors that will come online in the next decades will greatly increase our ability to observe gravitational waves at lower frequencies, including those from relatively common binary star systems whose stars have a wide range of masses and arbitrary spins.

We have in this project created a user-friendly computer program that accepts a list of parameters describing a binary star system’s physical characteristics and generates graphs and/or data files describing the gravitational wave such a system should produce during a specified period of time (according to Einstein’s theory of general relativity). The program runs on any reasonably recent personal computer. The accompanying graphs show waveforms produced by this program.

Including stellar spins in this computer model has been an especially challenging task that has taken years to accomplish, but relatively recent theoretical work by other groups has made this finally tractable. Our open-source program builds on this work to provide the research community with a new tool that others can use to generate templates for comparing to observed waveforms or as a reference for others testing other programs or methods for creating waveforms. Researchers can also easily modify the code for their own needs and/or to improve the accuracy of its approximations.

This project has created a website https://lisaresearch.sites.pomona.edu/ on which we plan in early 2025 to post the program source, compiled versions for various operating systems, descriptions of the physics and mathematics behind the code, and complete documentation of the program’s classes and methods. We also anticipate publishing a paper in 2025 describing the program and announcing its availability.

The project has also laid solid foundations for a more complicated open-source computer program that will simulate how a given gravitational wave detector will respond to such a gravitational wave. This (mostly finished) program will accept the list of a binary system’s parameters and describe the detector’s ability to determine those parameters from the received wave by computing the uncertainty in each parameter’s value induced by noise in the detector. This program could be used by researchers to help them decide on which sources to focus one’s efforts or even to determine the effects of detector design changes on the detector’s ability to do good science. The current version of the program focuses on simulating the proposed LISA gravitational wave detector, but can be straightforwardly modified to simulate other detectors.

When this simulation is finished, we will post it (with supporting documentation) on the previously mentioned website. More papers will also be forthcoming.

During its four-year period, this project has provided invaluable research opportunities for twelve different undergraduates. These students have learned about how research works (and sometimes doesn’t work) and about general relativity, gravitational wave generation and detection, parameter estimation, computer coding, version control, website creation, the value of teamwork, writing research reports, and creating posters. Some of these students have already carried what they have learned into physics graduate school, where it will help them become more experienced and productive scientists. Other students have also learned a bit about this project due to theses and presentations created by team members.

Though the NSF-funded portion of the project has ended, it has been instrumental in laying a foundation for work that is currently providing and will continue to provide research opportunities for students for some years in the future.
